title: 105_hr2369
content: The "Wireless Privacy Enhancement Act of 1998" may be cited as the short title. Commerce in electronic eavesdropping devices is addressed in the Act. The "Wireless Privacy Enhancement Act of 1998" prohibits the modification of devices that fail to comply with regulations and prohibits commerce in scanning receivers capable of breaching privacy. The "Wireless Privacy Enhancement Act of 1998" prohibits the modification of scanning receivers to receive transmissions in specific frequencies allocated to cellular and personal communications services, or equipped with decoders to convert digital transmissions to analog voice audio or alphanumeric text. The "Wireless Privacy Enhancement Act of 1998" prohibits unauthorized interception of encrypted radio transmissions and aims to enhance privacy for users of shared frequencies, while also considering prevention of tampering with scanning receivers. The "Wireless Privacy Enhancement Act of 1998" prohibits unauthorized interception of encrypted radio transmissions and aims to enhance privacy for users of shared frequencies. The Act precludes alteration of equipment features to prevent unlawful interception of radio communication. The Federal Communications Commission will prescribe regulations within 90 days to amend existing regulations for implementation. The Federal Communications Commission will prescribe amendments to its regulations to implement the changes made by the "Wireless Privacy Enhancement Act of 1998." SEC. 3. UNAUTHORIZED INTERCEPTION OR PUBLICATION OF COMMUNICATIONS. Section 705 of the Communications Act of 1934 (47 U.S.C. 605) is amended to include provisions regarding interception or disclosure of communications without authorization. Key changes include adding the word "interception" before "intentionally," allowing for interception or disclosure as authorized by law, and specifying exceptions for authorized interceptions under chapter 119 of title 18, United States Code. The amendments to Section 705 of the Communications Act of 1934 include changes to interception or disclosure of communications without authorization. These changes involve removing fines and specifying violations related to interception, divulgence, publication, or utilization of communications. The Commission has the authority to investigate and take action against violations of the Communications Act, including imposing forfeiture penalties. The House of Representatives passed the bill on March 5, 1998. Attest: ROBIN H. CARLE, Clerk.
